wp:Document.wp:Title: Yukon Web Based Cap Control Database

wp:Content.ctChapterTitle: Yukon Web Based Cap Control Database
wp:Content.boBody: The following sections describe how to create Cap Control database items using the Web-based Capacitor Control client.
wp:Content.noNote: NOTE To enable the Cap Control features of Yukon, you must purchase the Cap Control module. For more information about this module, contact a Cannon Technologies sales representative.
wp:Content.boBody: To access the Web based capacitor control client:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Start Internet Explorer and enter the address of the Yukon Web server.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Enter a username and password that has privileges to access the Web based capacitor control client.
Click Submit to log into the Web based capacitor control client.
wp:Content.boBody: The Cap Control database is used by the Cap Control Module to execute user-defined feeder or capacitor control strategies. Using Var, Watt, and Voltage data collected or received by the Yukon server, control strategies open or close capacitor banks to maintain a user-defined optimum Var, Power Factor, or Voltage level.
Use the following procedure to set up Capacitor Bank Control.
wp:Content.s1Step1: Create the capacitor bank controllers (CBC). A bank status point is created for the CBCs. For instructions, see "2.3. Cap Bank Controllers".
wp:Content.s2Step2: Create the capacitor banks. Operations and bank status points are automatically created for the Capacitor Banks. For instructions, see "2.4. Capacitor Banks".
During creation, you can select an existing capacitor bank controller (CBC) or create a new one.
Create the feeders on which the capacitor banks are located. For instructions, see "2.5. Feeders".
Create the substation buses on which the feeders are located. For instructions, see "2.6. Substation Buses". The control method is selected during Substation Bus creation.
Create the schedules which control when capacitor bank verification commands are sent. For instructions see, "2.7. Schedules".
Edit the points for the capacitor banks, capacitor bank controllers, feeders, and substation buses. For instructions, see "2.8. Cap Control Points".
wp:Content.boBody: A Capacitor Bank Controller (CBC) is a one-way device with control capability and is represented as a device on the Yukon system.
To create a CBC:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Click on Create and then select CBC.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Enter a name for the CBC in the Name text box.
To disable the CBC, select the Disabled check box.
Select the type of CBC from the CBC Type drop-down list.
wp:Content.sbuStepBullet: CBC ExpressCom - Capacitor Bank Controller using ExpressCom Protocol
CBC VERSACOM - Capacitor Bank Controller using VERSACOM Protocol
CBC 7010 - 900 MHz FLEX Paging
CBC 7011 - Cannon PLC
CBC 7012 - VHF Paging
CBC 7020 - Ethernet TCP/IP
CBC 7022 - GSM/GPRS
CBC 7023 - CDMA/1xRTT
CBC 7024 - Serial DNP 3.0
CBC FP-2800 - Fisher Pierce Capacitor Controller
wp:Content.s2Step2: If you selected a CBC 7020, CBC 7022, CBC 7023, or CBC 7024; select the comm channel used to communicate with the CBC from the Comm. Channel drop-down list.
Click Create to create the CBC.
wp:Content.boBody: After a CBC is created, the new cap bank controller appears in the CBC Editor.
An existing CBC can be edited by performing the following steps:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Search for a CBC by entering text to search for in the Find text box and clicking Go.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Select the check box of a CBC to edit.
Click on Modify and then select Edit.
wp:Content.boBody:
The CBCs general settings can be edited on this tab:
Table 2.1 General Tab
Field Name
Meaning
Type
The device type. A different type of CBC can be selected from the drop-down list.
Class
The device class.
Parent
The cap bank to which this CBC is assigned.
Name
The name for the CBC.
Disable
To disable the CBC, select the Disable check box.
To save any changes made in the CBC Editor, click the Submit button. To undo any changes made in the CBC Editor, click the Reset button. To return to the previous page, click the Return button.

If the CBC is a one-way device, the following CBCs setup settings can be edited on this tab:
Table 2.2 Setup Tab (One-Way)
Field Name
Meaning
Serial Number
Serial number of the CBC.
Control Route
Communication route used to control the CBC.
If the CBC is a two-way device, the following information appears on the Setup tab.

The CBCs configuration can be edited by selecting the Edit Controller check box:
Table 2.3 Setup Tab (Two-Way)
Field Name
Meaning
Serial Number
Serial number of the CBC.
Master Address
Master DNP address of the Master Station.
Slave Address
Slave DNP address identifier of the CBC.
Comm. Channel
Comm channel used to communicate with the CBC.
Post Comm Wait
Length of time the communication port waits before listening for a response.
Class 0,1,2,3 Scan
Collects all of the data on the device.
Class 1,2,3 Scan
Collects the data that has changed since the last scan.
Interval
Default scan rate for the scan category.
Alt Interval
The alternate interval can be activated using the Web interface and is used during the "control timeout" period to collect the state of a control point.
Scan Group
Scan groups allow priorities to be assigned to scan categories.
A two-way CBC has status, analog, and accumulator points assigned to it by default. To edit a point, click on the name of the point. To create a new point, click on the Add Point link.
For instructions on creating and editing points, refer to "2.8. Cap Control Points".

When a capacitor bank is created, the information stored in the database includes the bank size in kVar, the location of the cap bank, a status point, and a control point. The control point can be any controllable status point in the Yukon database. This could be a point off an RTU; however, it is most likely a point from a CBC. A cap bank without a control point setting represents a fixed Cap Bank. An additional operations counter point is supported, which increments by one for every open or closed operation.
To create a Cap Bank:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Click on Create and then select Cap Bank.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Enter a name for the capacitor bank in the Name text box.
To disable the capacitor bank, select the Disabled check box.
To create a new capacitor bank controller and assign it to the capacitor bank, select the Create New CBC check box.
wp:Content.saStepA: Enter a name for the CBC in the Controller Name text box.
wp:Content.sbStepB: Select the type of CBC from the CBC Type drop-down list.
wp:Content.d2Dash2: CBC ExpressCom - Capacitor Bank Controller using ExpressCom Protocol
CBC VERSACOM - Capacitor Bank Controller using VERSACOM Protocol
CBC FP-2800 - Fisher Pierce Capacitor Controller
wp:Content.sbStepB: If you select CBC 7020, CBC 7022, CBC 7023, or CBC 7024; you must also select the comm channel used to communicate with the CBC from the Comm. Channel drop-down list.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Click Create to create the capacitor bank and optional capacitor bank controller.
wp:Content.boBody: After a capacitor bank is created, the new cap bank appears in the Capacitor Bank Editor.
An existing capacitor bank can be edited by performing the following steps:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Display the feeders page that contains the capacitor bank to edit or search for the capacitor bank by entering text to search for in the Find text box and clicking Go.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Select the check box of a capacitor bank to edit.
Click on Modify and then select Edit.
wp:Content.boBody:
The capacitor bank general settings can be edited in the General area:
Table 2.4 General Tab
Field Name
Meaning
Type
The device type.
Class
The device class.
Parent
The feeder to which this cap bank is assigned.
Name
The name for the capacitor bank.
Disable
To disable the capacitor bank, select the Disable check box.

To save any changes made in the Capacitor Bank Editor, click the Submit button. To undo any changes made in the Capacitor Bank Editor, click the Reset button. To return to the previous page, click the Return button.

Additional information about the capacitor bank can be entered in the Information area.
Table 2.5 Capacitor Bank Information
Field Name
Meaning
Address
Street address or geographical location of the cap bank.
Map Location ID
Map ID of the cap bank.
Switch Manufacturer
Manufacturer of the cap bank switch.
Controller Type
Type of cap bank controller.
Type of Switch
Type of cap bank switch.

The capacitor bank configuration settings can be edited in the configuration area:
Table 2.6 Cap Bank Configuration
Field Name
Meaning
Operation Method
Fixed - the cap bank cannot be remotely opened or closed.
Stand Alone - the CBC attached to the cap bank operates on time, temperature, voltage, neutral current, or digital/analog inputs. The cap bank cannot be remotely opened or closed.
Switched - the cap bank can be remotely opened or closed with a CBC.
Uninstalled - the cap bank or the CBC attached to the cap bank has been uninstalled.
Bank Size
Size of the cap bank in kVar.
Reclose Delay
This is the amount time after a trip command is sent before the relay can be closed.
Control Point
A control point is typically a point that operates the cap bank. To assign a control point to a cap bank, click the + next to the desired device type, click the + next to the desired device, and select the point to assign to the cap bank. To unassign a control point, click the No Control Point link.

The number of maximum daily operations can be defined in the Cap Bank Operations area.
Table 2.7 Capacitor Bank Daily Operations
Field Name
Meaning
Max Daily Operations
Maximum number of daily capacitor bank operations.
Disable upon reaching max operations
Select this check box to disable a capacitor bank if it performs the maximum number of daily operations.
CapBank Points
Bank Status - Status of the cap bank (Open or Closed).
Operation - Number of cap bank operations.

If the control point is from a CBC, the following information appears in the Controller Information area:
Table 2.8 Controller Information
Field Name
Meaning
CBC Controller
Name of the CBC.
Serial #
Serial number of the CBC.
Control Route
Route or route macro used to communicate with the CBC.

If the controller is a two-way CBC, the following information appears in the Controller Information area:
Table 2.9 CBC 7020 Controller Information
Field Name
Meaning
CBC Controller
Serial number of the CBC.
Master Address
Master DNP address of the Master Station.
Slave Address
Slave DNP address identifier of the CBC.
Comm. Channel
Comm channel used to communicate with the CBC.
Post Comm. Wait
Length of time the communication port waits before listening for a response.
Class 0,1,2,3 Scan
Collects all of the data on the device.
Class 1,2,3 Scan
Collects the data that has changed since the last scan.
Interval
Default scan rate for the scan category.
Alt Interval
The alternate interval can be activated using the Web interface and is used during the "control timeout" period to collect the state of a control point.
Scan Group
Scan groups allow priorities to be assigned to scan categories.
wp:Content.noNote: NOTE To edit the controller information, click on the name of the CBC.
wp:Content.boBody: To save any changes made in the Capacitor Bank Editor, click the Submit button. To undo any changes made in the Capacitor Bank Editor, click the Reset button. To return to the previous page, click the Return button.

The following information appears in the Point Assignment section of the Advanced tab:
Table 2.10 Point Assignment
Field Name
Meaning
Available Points
Points that can be assigned to the cap bank. To assign a point to the cap bank, click Add >>.
Assigned Points
Points that are assigned to the cap bank. To remove a point from the cap bank, click << Remove.

If a point is assigned to the cap bank, the following information appears in the Point Configuration section of the Advanced tab:
Table 2.11 Point Configuration
Field Name
Meaning
Override feeder limits
To override the upper and lower bandwidth limits defined in the control strategy, click the Override feeder limits check box.
Upper Bandwidth
If the Override feeder limits check box is selected, enter an upper voltage bandwidth in the Upper Bandwidth text box.
Lower Bandwidth
If the Override feeder limits check box is selected, enter a lower voltage bandwidth in the Lower Bandwidth text box.
Initiate scan on unsolicited
To allow the cap bank to be scanned after an unsolicited event, select the Initiate scan on unsolicited check box.
Adaptive Count
To change the number of voltage point readings that the an voltage average is calculated from, enter a new value in the Adaptive Count text box.

To save any changes made in the Capacitor Bank Editor, click the Submit button. To undo any changes made in the Capacitor Bank Editor, click the Reset button. To return to the previous page, click the Return button.
Feeders are the distribution lines coming from the transformer in the substation.
To create a feeder:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Click on Create and the select Feeder.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Enter a name for the feeder in the Name text box.
To disable the feeder, select the Disabled check box.
wp:Content.i1Indent1: Disabling the feeder prevents the Yukon server from using the feeder. This is useful if maintenance is being performed on cap banks located on the feeder.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Click Create to create the feeder.
wp:Content.boBody: After a feeder is created, the new feeder appears in the Feeder Editor.
An existing feeder can be edited by performing the following steps:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Display the feeders page that contains the feeder to edit or search for the feeder by entering text to search for in the Find text box and clicking Go.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Select the check box of a feeder to edit.
Click on Modify and then select Edit.
wp:Content.boBody:
Enter information about the feeder into the following fields:
Table 2.12 General Tab
Field Name
Meaning
Type
The device type.
Class
The device class.
Parent
The substation bus to which this feeder is assigned.
Name
The name for the feeder.
Disable
To disable the feeder, select the Disable check box.
To save any changes made in the Feeder Editor, click the Submit button. To undo any changes made in the Feeder Editor, click the Reset button. To return to the previous page, click the Return button.

Enter information about the feeder into the following fields:
Table 2.13 Feeder - General Settings
Field Name
Meaning
Map Location ID
Optional map ID of the feeder.
VAR Point
VAR point on the cap control system. This can be a real, pseudo, or calculated point.
Watt Point
Watt point on the cap control system that used with the VAR point for Power Factor Control. This can be a real, pseudo, or calculated point.
Volt Point
Voltage point on the cap control system. This can be a real, pseudo, or calculated point.
To save any changes made in the Feeder Editor, click the Submit button. To undo any changes made in the Feeder Editor, click the Reset button. To return to the previous page, click the Return button.

The following information appears in the strategy detail area:
Table 2.14 Feeder - Strategy Detail
Field Name
Meaning
Strategy Name
Name for the control strategy.
Control Method
IndividualFeeder - uses each feeder's Var load and set point to control the cap banks on each feeder. Each feeder operates independently and switches the banks according to their ordered list. The bank list is searched beginning to end looking for an available bank to switch on (close) or from end to beginning looking to a bank to turn off (open).
BusOptimizedFeeder - uses the substation bus Vars and set point to control cap banks. This control method evaluates and selects a bank from the feeder with the worst Var level. This maintains optimum Var levels on both the substation bus and feeders.
Manually Only - cap banks are controlled by manually sent commands.
SubstationBus - uses the substation bus Vars and set point to control cap banks. This control method selects a bank by alternating between feeders and their bank ordered list. This allows it to switch the first bank on each feeder before taking the second banks.
Analysis Interval
How often cap control determines if control is needed.
The default value of On New Data Only causes cap control to determine if control is needed whenever the Var point is updated.
Max Confirm Time
Maximum number of minutes to wait after a control is sent before allowing another control.
Pass Percent
Percentage of the cap bank's size that is used as the minimum expected Var load change for the operation to be considered confirmed successfully.
Failure Percent
Percentage of the cap bank's size that is used as a failure threshold. If the Var change value is below this value, the operation is considered failed.
Send Retries
Number of times the control command can be sent if a change is not seen.
Delay Time
Amount of time to wait between sending retries.

The following information appears in the strategy peaks area:
Table 2.15 Feeder - Strategy Peaks
Field Name
Meaning
Control Algorithm
kVAr - control is determined using VAr values.
P-Factor kW/kVAr - control is determined using Power Factor values calculated from kW and kVAr.
Multi Volt - control is determined using voltage values from monitor points.
VOLTS - control is determined using system voltage values.
Multi Volt VAr - control is determined using voltage and VAr values from monitor points.
Peak Start Time
Start time of the peak time period.
Peak Stop Time
Stop time of the peak time period.
Peak Settings
The control algorithm uses these settings during the peak time period.
Off Peak Settings
The control algorithm uses these settings during the off peak time period.
wp:Content.i1Indent1: For the kVar control algorithm, the following settings appear:
wp:Content.sbuStepBullet: VAr Leading - If the measured VAr value is below the VAr Leading value, then the system may open a Cap Bank to increase the VAr level.
VAr Lagging - If the measured VAr value is above the VAr Lagging value, then the system may close a Cap Bank to reduce the VAr level.
wp:Content.i1Indent1: For the Power Factor control algorithm, the following settings appear:
wp:Content.sbuStepBullet: Target PF - Target Power factor (a negative value indicates leading).
Min. of Bank Open - If the Var value is below the Bank Open percentage of the bank size, then the system may open a Cap Bank to make the power factor closer to the Target PF.
Min. of Bank Close - If the VAr value is above the Bank Close percentage of the bank size, then the system may close a Cap Bank to make the power factor closer to the Target PF.
wp:Content.i1Indent1: For the VOLTS control algorithm, the following settings appear:
wp:Content.sbuStepBullet: Upper Volt Limit - If the Voltage level is above the Upper Volt Limit, then the system may open a Cap Bank to decrease the voltage level.
Lower Volt Limit - If the Voltage level is below the Lower Volt Limit, then the system may close a Cap Bank to increase the voltage level.
wp:Content.i1Indent1: For the Multi Volt control algorithm, the following settings appear:
wp:Content.sbuStepBullet: Upper Volt Limit - If the Voltage level of one or more monitor points is above the Upper Volt Limit, then the system may close a Cap Bank to decrease the voltage level.
Lower Volt Limit - If the Voltage level of one or more monitor points is below the Lower Volt Limit, then the system may close a Cap Bank to increase the voltage level.
wp:Content.i1Indent1: For the Multi Volt Var control algorithm, the following settings appear:
wp:Content.sbuStepBullet: Upper Volt Limit - If the Voltage level of one or more monitor points is above the Upper Volt Limit, then the system may close a Cap Bank to decrease the voltage level.
Lower Volt Limit - If the Voltage level of one or more monitor points is below the Lower Volt Limit, then the system may close a Cap Bank to increase the voltage level.

VAr Leading - If the Voltage level of one or more monitor points is between the Upper Volt Limit and Lower Volt Limit and the measured VAr value is below the VAr Leading value, then the system may open a Cap Bank to increase the VAr level.

VAr Lagging - If the Voltage level of one or more monitor points is between the Upper Volt Limit and Lower Volt Limit and the measured VAr value is above the VAr Lagging value, then the system may close a Cap Bank to reduce the VAr level.
wp:Content.boBody:
The number of maximum daily operations can be defined in the Strategy Operations area.
Table 2.16 Feeder - Strategy Operations
Field Name
Meaning
Max Daily Operation
To set the maximum daily operations, select this check box and enter the maximum number of daily operations in the text box.
Disable sub after reaching max op count
To disable the substation bus after the max daily operation count is reached, select this check box.
The peak days can be defined in the Peak Operating Days area.
To save any changes made in the Feeder Editor, click the Submit button. To undo any changes made in the Feeder Editor, click the Reset button. To return to the previous page, click the Return button.

The following information appears on the Cap Banks tab:
Table 2.17 Feeder - Cap Banks
List Name
Meaning
Available Cap Banks
Cap banks that can be assigned to the feeder. To assign a cap bank to the feeder, click Add.
Assigned Cap Banks
Cap banks that are assigned to the feeder. To remove a cap bank from the feeder, click Remove.
To rearrange the order of the assigned cap banks, change the values in the Order text boxes and click Submit.
wp:Content.noNote: NOTE If more than one page of Available Cap Banks exists, use the controls below the table to display the additional cap banks.
wp:Content.boBody: To save any changes made in the Feeder Editor, click the Submit button. To undo any changes made in the Feeder Editor, click the Reset button. To return to the previous page, click the Return button.
Substation buses are the transformer buses in the substation.
To create a substation bus:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Click on Create and then select Substation.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Enter a name for the substation bus in the Name text box.
To disable the substation bus, select the Disabled check box.
wp:Content.i1Indent1: Disabling the substation bus prevents the Yukon server from using the substation bus. This is useful if maintenance is being performed on cap banks located on the sub bus.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Click Create to create the substation bus.
wp:Content.boBody: After a substation bus is created, the new sub bus appears in the Substation Bus Editor.
An existing substation bus can be edited by performing the following steps:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Display the substations page that contains the substation bus to edit or search for the substation bus by entering text to search for in the Find text box and clicking Go.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Select the check box of a substation bus to edit.
Click on Modify and then select Edit.
wp:Content.boBody:
Enter information about the substation bus into the following fields:
Table 2.18 Substation Bus - General Tab
Field Name
Meaning
Type
The device type.
Class
The device class.
Parent
Another device, to which this substation bus is assigned.
Name
The name for the substation bus.
Disable
To disable the substation bus, select the Disable check box.

To save any changes made in the Substation Bus Editor, click the Submit button. To undo any changes made in the Substation Bus Editor, click the Reset button. To return to the previous page, click the Return button.

Enter information about the substation bus into the following fields:
Table 2.19 Substation Bus - Setup
Field Name
Meaning
Geographical Name
Name of the geographical area of the substation bus.
Map Location ID
Optional map ID of the substation bus.
VAR Point
VAR point on the cap control system. This can be a real, pseudo, or calculated point.
Watt Point
Watt point on the cap control system that used with the VAR point for Power Factor Control. This can be a real, pseudo, or calculated point.
Volt Point
Voltage point on the cap control system. This can be a real, pseudo, or calculated point.

To save any changes made in the Substation Bus Editor, click the Submit button. To undo any changes made in the Substation Bus Editor, click the Reset button. To return to the previous page, click the Return button.

Enter information about the substation bus into the following fields:
Table 2.20 Substation Bus - Schedule
Field Name
Meaning
Schedule
How often to send a verify command to the cap banks on the substation bus.
Outgoing Command
Type of verify command to send to the cap banks on the substation bus.

To save any changes made in the Substation Bus Editor, click the Submit button. To undo any changes made in the Substation Bus Editor, click the Reset button. To return to the previous page, click the Return button.

The following information appears in the strategy detail area:
Table 2.21 Substation Bus - Strategy Detail
Field Name
Meaning
Strategy Name
Name for the control strategy.
Control Method
IndividualFeeder - uses each feeder's Var load and set point to control the cap banks on each feeder. Each feeder operates independently and switches the banks according to their ordered list. The bank list is searched beginning to end looking for an available bank to switch on (close) or from end to beginning looking to a bank to turn off (open).
BusOptimizedFeeder - uses the substation bus Vars and set point to control cap banks. This control method evaluates and selects a bank from the feeder with the worst Var level. This maintains optimum Var levels on both the substation bus and feeders.
Manually Only - cap banks are controlled by manually sent commands.
SubstationBus - uses the substation bus Vars and set point to control cap banks. This control method selects a bank by alternating between feeders and their bank ordered list. This allows it to switch the first bank on each feeder before taking the second banks.
Analysis Interval
How often cap control determines if control is needed.
The default value of On New Data Only causes cap control to determine if control is needed whenever the Var point is updated.
Max Confirm Time
Maximum number of minutes to wait after a control is sent before allowing another control.
Pass Percent
Percentage of the cap bank's size that is used as the minimum expected Var load change for the operation to be considered confirmed successfully.
Failure Percent
Percentage of the cap bank's size that is used as a failure threshold. If the Var change value is below this value, the operation is considered failed.
Send Retries
Number of times the control command can be sent if a change is not seen.
Delay Time
Amount of time to wait between sending retries.

The following information appears in the strategy peaks area:
Table 2.22 Feeder - Strategy Peaks
Field Name
Meaning
Control Algorithm
kVAr - control is determined using VAr values.
P-Factor kW/kVAr - control is determined using Power Factor values calculated from kW and kVAr.
Multi Volt - control is determined using voltage monitor points.
VOLTS - control is determined using system voltage values.
Multi Volt VAr - control is determined using voltage and VAr monitor points.
Peak Start Time
Start time of the peak time period.
Peak Stop Time
Stop time of the peak time period.
Peak Settings
The control algorithm uses these settings during the peak time period.
Off Peak Settings
The control algorithm uses these settings during the off peak time period.
wp:Content.i1Indent1: For the kVar control algorithm, the following settings appear:
wp:Content.sbuStepBullet: VAr Leading - If the measured VAr value is below the VAr Leading value, then the system may open a Cap Bank to increase the VAr level.
VAr Lagging - If the measured VAr value is above the VAr Lagging value, then the system may close a Cap Bank to reduce the VAr level.
wp:Content.i1Indent1: For the Power Factor control algorithm, the following settings appear:
wp:Content.sbuStepBullet: Target PF - Target Power factor (a negative value indicates leading).
Min. of Bank Open - If the Var value is below the Bank Open percentage of the bank size, then the system may open a Cap Bank to make the power factor closer to the Target PF.
Min. of Bank Close - If the VAr value is above the Bank Close percentage of the bank size, then the system may close a Cap Bank to make the power factor closer to the Target PF.
wp:Content.i1Indent1: For the VOLTS control algorithm, the following settings appear:
wp:Content.sbuStepBullet: Upper Volt Limit - If the Voltage level is above the Upper Volt Limit, then the system may open a Cap Bank to decrease the voltage level.
Lower Volt Limit - If the Voltage level is below the Lower Volt Limit, then the system may close a Cap Bank to increase the voltage level.
wp:Content.i1Indent1: For the Multi Volt control algorithm, the following settings appear:
wp:Content.sbuStepBullet: Upper Volt Limit - If the Voltage level of one or more monitor points is above the Upper Volt Limit, then the system may close a Cap Bank to decrease the voltage level.
Lower Volt Limit - If the Voltage level of one or more monitor points is below the Lower Volt Limit, then the system may close a Cap Bank to increase the voltage level.
wp:Content.i1Indent1: For the Multi Volt Var control algorithm, the following settings appear:
wp:Content.sbuStepBullet: Upper Volt Limit - If the Voltage level of one or more monitor points is above the Upper Volt Limit, then the system may close a Cap Bank to decrease the voltage level.
Lower Volt Limit - If the Voltage level of one or more monitor points is below the Lower Volt Limit, then the system may close a Cap Bank to increase the voltage level.

VAr Leading - If the Voltage level of one or more monitor points is between the Upper Volt Limit and Lower Volt Limit and the measured VAr value is below the VAr Leading value, then the system may open a Cap Bank to increase the VAr level.

VAr Lagging - If the Voltage level of one or more monitor points is between the Upper Volt Limit and Lower Volt Limit and the measured VAr value is above the VAr Lagging value, then the system may close a Cap Bank to reduce the VAr level.
wp:Content.boBody:
The number of maximum daily operations can be defined in the Strategy Operations area.
Table 2.23 Substation Bus - Strategy Operations
Field Name
Meaning
Max Daily Operation
To set the maximum daily operations, select this check box and enter the maximum number of daily operations in the text box.
Disable sub after reaching max op count
To disable the substation bus after the max daily operation count is reached, select this check box.
The peak days can be defined in the Peak Operating Days area.

To save any changes made in the Substation Bus Editor, click the Submit button. To undo any changes made in the Substation Bus Editor, click the Reset button. To return to the previous page, click the Return button.

The following information appears on the Feeders tab:
Table 2.24 Substation Bus - Feeders
List Name
Meaning
Available Feeders
Feeders that can be assigned to the substation bus. To assign a feeder to the substation, click Add.
Assigned Feeders
Feeders that are assigned to the substation bus. To remove a feeder from the substation bus, click << Remove.
To rearrange the order of the assigned feeders, change the values in the Order text boxes and click Submit.
wp:Content.noNote: NOTE If more than one page of Available Feeders exists, use the controls below the table to display the additional feeders.
wp:Content.boBody: The following features can be configured on the Advanced tab:

To enable the Alternate Substation Bus feature, select the Enable Dual Bus check box. The Alternate Substation Bus feature allows the user to select a Substation Bus to switch to if the selected Switch Point changes states.

The Switch Point is typically a calculated point which determines whether or not substation values received from an RTU are valid. A point value of 0 indicates the value are valid, while a point value of 1 indicates the values are invalid, which causes the system to start using values from the Alternate Substation Bus.

To save any changes made in the Substation Bus Editor, click the Submit button. To undo any changes made in the Substation Bus Editor, click the Reset button. To return to the previous page, click the Return button.
If the Enable Dual Bus check box is not selected, the user can select a point that will cause the Substation Bus to be disabled if the status of the point changes.

The Disable Point is typically a calculated point which determines whether or not substation values received from an RTU are valid. A point value of 0 indicates the value are valid, while a point value of 1 indicates the values are invalid, which causes the system to disable the Substation bus.

To save any changes made in the Substation Bus Editor, click the Submit button. To undo any changes made in the Substation Bus Editor, click the Reset button. To return to the previous page, click the Return button.
Schedules are used to control when verification commands are sent to capacitor banks.
To create a schedule:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Click on Create and then select Schedule.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Enter a name for the schedule in the Name text box.
To disable the schedule, select the Disabled check box.
wp:Content.i1Indent1: Disabling the schedule prevents the Yukon server from using that schedule to send out verification commands.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Click Create to create the schedule.
wp:Content.boBody: After a schedule is created, the new sub bus appears in the Schedule Editor.
An existing schedule can be edited by performing the following steps:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Display all schedules by clicking on View and selecting Schedules.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Click on the Edit link of the schedule to edit.
wp:Content.boBody:
Enter information about the schedule into the following fields:
Table 2.25 Schedule - General Tab
Field Name
Meaning
Name
The name for the substation bus.
Disable
To disable the substation bus, select the Disable check box.

To save any changes made in the Schedule Editor, click the Submit button. To undo any changes made in the Schedule Editor, click the Reset button. To return to the previous page, click the Return button.

Enter information about the schedule into the following fields:
Table 2.26 Schedule - Schedule Tab
Field Name
Meaning
Repeat Interval
How often to a scheduled task. (5 minutes to 30 days, or None)
Next Run Time
The next run time of the schedule. (Day, Month, Year, Time)
Info
Displays the last time the schedule ran.

To save any changes made in the Schedule Editor, click the Submit button. To undo any changes made in the Schedule Editor, click the Reset button.. To return to the previous page, click the Return button.
Cap control points allow for tracking of cap control data.
A cap control point may be one of the following types:
wp:Content.buBullet: Analog - reads a value directly from the transducer or electronic device.
Status - reads the value of a contact, usually open or closed. An example of a status point might be the relay on the switch of a capacitor bank.
Accumulator - measures any quantity that is a simple count accumulation, such as the number of pulses.
Calculated - calculates data gathered from other points.
wp:Content.boBody: To add a point to a CBC:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Edit the CBC to which you want to add the point.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Under the Analog and Status Points area, click the Add Point link.
Enter a name for the point in the Name text box.
Select one of the following from the Point Type drop-down list:
wp:Content.sbuStepBullet: Analog
Status
Accumulator
Calculated
wp:Content.s2Step2: If the point type is Calculated, select the output type for the point from the Calc. Output drop-down list. The options are Analog Output or Status Output.
Click Create.
wp:Content.boBody: The Point Editor contains tabbed pages the following tabs: General, Physical Setup, Limits, Foreign Data, and Alarms. The General and Physical Setup tabbed pages provide different options depending on the type of point.
To modify a point:
wp:Content.s1Step1: Enter the name of a point to search for in the Find text box and click Go.
wp:Content.s2Step2: Select the check box if the point to modify.
Click on Modify and then select Edit.
wp:Content.boBody:
The general settings of the point can be changed in the following fields:
Table 2.27 Analog Point - General Settings
Field Name
Meaning
Point Name
Name of the point.
Timing Group
A value of Default records events that occur within seconds of each other.
For points on DNP devices, a value of SOE (Sequence of Events) can be selected, which records high speed events that occur within milliseconds of each other.
Disable Point
The point can be disabled or enabled by selecting or clearing this check box. Disabling the point may be useful if it is temporarily not functioning.
Archive Data
The data archive types are: • None - does not archive. • On Change - archives when an operand causes the point to change. • On Timer - archives at the selected archive interval. • On Update - archives any time the point is updated.
Interval
Controls how often the point data is archived. This field is enabled only when On Timer is selected as the Data Type.
Unit of Measure
The unit of measure is for the actual data being read.
Decimal Digits
Number of decimal places to display for the measurement
To save any changes made in the Point Editor, click the Submit button. To undo any changes made in the Point Editor, click the Reset button. To return to the previous page, click the Return button.

The general settings of the point can be changed in the following fields:
Table 2.28 Status Points - General Settings
Field Name
Meaning
Point Name
Name of the point.
Timing Group
A value of Default records events that occur within seconds of each other.
For points on DNP devices, a value of SOE (Sequence of Events) can be selected, which records high speed events that occur within milliseconds of each other.
Disable Point
The point can be disabled or enabled by selecting or clearing this check box. Disabling the point may be useful if it is temporarily not functioning.
Archive
Select this check box to send information to the raw point table. Generally, only points of particular significance are sent to this table.
State Group
Defines the messages to display for the different states of a point.
Initial State
Initial state of the point. The initial state depends on the state group selected.
To save any changes made in the Point Editor, click the Submit button. To undo any changes made in the Point Editor, click the Reset button. To return to the previous page, click the Return button.

The physical settings of the point can be changed in the following fields:
Table 2.29 Analog Point - Physical Settings
Field Name
Meaning
Point Offset
The point offset is the physical relay used for wiring.
Deadband
This is the amount a reading must deviate before the value is read and updated.
Multiplier
The multiplier converts pulses into kWh (visual meter reading) and is used to calculate the unit value.
Data Offset
This is the value that gets added to the point when making a calculation. For example, the data offset can be the Y-intercept for linear calculations.
Limit 1
Limit 2
To enable the high and low limits, select the Limit 1 and/or Limit 2 check boxes, then enter limit values in the High and Low text boxes.
High
Low
High and low values for the limit(s). If a value goes outside this range, the limit is violated and an alarm is generated.
Duration
The number of seconds that Limit 1 or Limit 2 must be exceeded before an alarm notification can occur.
High Reasonability
Low Reasonability
To enable the reasonability limits, select the High Reasonability and/or Low Reasonability check boxes, then enter reasonability limit values in the text boxes. If a reading exceeds a reasonability limit, the reading is ignored.
To save any changes made in the Point Editor, click the Submit button. To undo any changes made in the Point Editor, click the Reset button. To return to the previous page, click the Return button.

The physical settings of the point can be changed in the following fields:
Table 2.30 Status Point - Physical Settings
Field Name
Meaning
Point Offset
The point offset is the physical relay used for wiring.
Control Inhibit
Select this check box to disable control of the point. Clear this check box to enable control of the point.a
Control Type
The control types are: • None - no control type exists. • Latch - control command is sent and the relay latches in that position. Latch controls require a second command to return to the original state. • Normal - control is a dual relay Select Before Operate (SBO). Normal controls are temporary or held only for a discrete number of milliseconds. • Pseudo - the point is controlled by another system. Pseudo controls do not have a physical status point to indicate if control has completed. • SBO Latch - Select Before Operate latch command. • SBO Pulse - Select Before Operate pulse (normal) command.
Control Pt. Offset
This specifies the physical location used for wiring the relay point.1
Close Time 1/
Close Time 2
These times specify the length of time that each relay stays energized.a
Command Timeout
This specifies the length of time to use the alternate scan rate to scan for a state change following control. If a state change is not detected, an alarm occurs.a
(command strings)
The command strings can be changed in the text boxes. These are the commands that are sent when Yukon controls the point.a
1Editable only if Latch, Normal, SBO Latch, or SBO Pulse is selected as the control type.
To save any changes made in the Point Editor, click the Submit button. To undo any changes made in the Point Editor, click the Reset button. To return to the previous page, click the Return button.

The alarm settings can be changed in the following fields:
Table 2.31 Alarm Settings
Field Name
Meaning
Notification Group
Notification group that is notified of all alarm conditions.
Contact
Customer contact who is notified of all alarm conditions.
Notify when alarms are Acknowledged
If this check box is selected, the notification group and contact receive a message whenever an alarm is acknowledged.
Notify when alarms are Cleared
If this check box is selected, the notification group and contact receive a message whenever an alarm is cleared.
Disable All Alarms
If this check box is selected, all of the alarms for this point are disabled.
Condition
Alarm conditions for the point.
Category
Alarm categories can be selected for each alarm condition.
Notify
(Attributes)
None - the notification is sent out normally.
Exclude Notify - the notification group/contact do not receive notification of the alarm.
Auto Ack - the alarm is automatically acknowledged.
Exclude Notify & Auto Ack - the notification group/contact do not receive notification of the alarm and the alarm is automatically acknowledged.
To save any changes made in the Point Editor, click the Submit button. To undo any changes made in the Point Editor, click the Reset button. To return to the previous page, click the Return button.
Foreign data routing allows you to specify interfaces to supported SCADA systems.
To add a new Foreign Data Routing entry, click the New Routing button.

To delete a Foreign Data Entry, click the (Delete)
button.
Table 2.32 Foreign Data Settings
Field Name
Meaning
Interface
FDR interface. The available interfaces are: ACS, ACSMULTI, BEPC, CYGNET, DSM2FILEIN, DSM2IMPORT, INET, LIVEDATA, LODESTAR_ENH, LOADSTAR_STD, PI, RCCS, RDEX, STEC, SYSTEM, TELGYR, TEXTEXPORT, TEXTIMPORT, TRISTATE, VALMET, and XA21LM.
Direction
Data direction, which controls whether the data is sent or received.
Translation
Depending on the Interface selected, different options appear under the Translation area. To edit the translation settings, click the (Edit) button. • If you selected ACS, select Pseudo, Real, or Calculated from the Category drop-down list, enter the remote name in the Remote text box, and enter the point name in the Point text box. • If you selected ACSMULTI, select Pseudo, Real, or Calculated from the Category drop-down list, enter the remote name in the Remote text box, enter the point name in the Point text box, and enter a destination or source in the Destination/Source text box. • If you selected CYGNET, TEXTEXPORT, or TEXTIMPORT, enter the point ID in the PointID text box. • If you selected DSM2FILEIN, enter the option number in the Option Number text box and the point ID in the Point ID text box. • If you selected DSM2IMPORT, or VALMET, enter the point name into the Point text box. • If you selected INET or RCCS, enter the device name in the Device text box, the point name in the Point text box, and the destination/source in the Destination/Source text box.
Translation (Continued)
• If you selected LIVEDATA, enter the address in the Address text box and select the type of data from the Data Type drop-down list. • If you selected LODESTAR_ENH or LOADSTAR_STD, enter the customer in the Customer text box, the channel in the Channel text box, the drive path in the DrivePath text box, and the filename in the Filename text box. • If you selected PI, enter the tag name of the point in the Tag Name text box. If the polling method is being used, enter how often to poll the PI database in the Period (sec) text box. If the notification method is being used, do not enter a value in the Period (sec) text box. • If you selected RDEX, enter the translation name in the Translation text box and the destination/source in the Destination/Source text box. • If you selected STEC or TRISTATE, select the point from the Point drop-down list. • If you selected SYSTEM, enter the client name in the Client text box. • If you selected TELEGYR, enter the point name in the Point text box and select a group from the Group drop-down list. If you selected XA21LM, enter the point number of the point on the XA/21 system in the Translation text box.
To save any changes made in the Point Editor, click the Submit button. To undo any changes made in the Point Editor, click the Reset button. To return to the previous page, click the Return button.
